text: Yeah, my understanding is that permitting from various depts is slow due to bureaucracy & the BoS won't step up to enforce faster timeline (or prevent/end needless DR that adds months or years to process). The prop goes over their heads to enforce a 6mo max on issuing permits.
text_html: Yeah, my understanding is that permitting from various depts is slow due to bureaucracy & the BoS won't step up to enforce faster timeline (or prevent/end needless DR that adds months or years to process). The prop goes over their heads to enforce a 6mo max on issuing permits.

text: Fairly certain she can't fix the DR problem on her own—it's dependent on the (majority home-owning) Board of Supervisors. @sfplanning apparently drafted up some major DR reform from 2008-2010, and the supes killed it. https://web.archive.org/web/20120315213316/http://www.sf-planning.org/index.aspx?page=1891 …
text_html: Fairly certain she can't fix the DR problem on her own—it's dependent on the (majority home-owning) Board of Supervisors. @sfplanning apparently drafted up some major DR reform from 2008-2010, and the supes killed it. https://web.archive.org/web/20120315213316/http://www.sf-planning.org/index.aspx?page=1891 …

text:
If the city perfectly recouped all of the value of an upzoning, then the land won’t be redeveloped. What would be the point from the land owners point of view? 
That’s why the idea seems strange. Why do an upzoning, then discourage redevelopment?
text_html: If the city perfectly recouped all of the value of an upzoning, then the land won’t be redeveloped. What would be the point from the land owners point of view? That’s why the idea seems strange. Why do an upzoning, then discourage redevelopment?

text: I don’t understand the notion that there isn’t value capture - wouldn’t property tax revenues be higher from a 10 unit building than 2 units on a lot?
text_html: I don’t understand the notion that there isn’t value capture - wouldn’t property tax revenues be higher from a 10 unit building than 2 units on a lot?

text: I agree that the city needs to find funding sources to secure efficient transportation infrastructure. But the less we build, and the longer we wait, the more the poor, working class, and even middle class will suffer from high rents and home prices.
text_html: I agree that the city needs to find funding sources to secure efficient transportation infrastructure. But the less we build, and the longer we wait, the more the poor, working class, and even middle class will suffer from high rents and home prices.

CENTRAL SOMA STARTING!

text: how about, if an upzoning increases value of a property from X to 2X, which owner then sells? How much of that revenue do you think it would it be fair to assess as tax?
text_html: how about, if an upzoning increases value of a property from X to 2X, which owner then sells? How much of that revenue do you think it would it be fair to assess as tax?

text:
Taxes are great, taxes pay for public services, and taxes should be collected from income streams. 

If an upzoning causes a person to build something, then we should tax the ongoing revenue produced by that thing, not have one lump sum tax at the beginning.
text_html: Taxes are great, taxes pay for public services, and taxes should be collected from income streams. If an upzoning causes a person to build something, then we should tax the ongoing revenue produced by that thing, not have one lump sum tax at the beginning.

text: The primary reliability benefits here come from red carpet lanes on 16th which is unrelated to how well integrated the 55 is. I’m not a transfer *advocate*, i try to avoid them when possible, Muni Metro just goes to ludicrously terrible extremes—jamming itself up—to avoid them.

text_html: Also: the T third should really align with Caltrain correctly and move substantially faster, so that it would be a reasonable choice for transferring from Caltrain to all points third street/Bayview/dogpatch

text:
The 55 is garbage (there, I said it) and I’m not sure 15-20 min frequency is all that frequent.

I agree it’s not a clear win for 16th, but pier 70 is still easily a half mile walk from 22nd street. 

If we achieve metro-level Caltrain service, there’s an argument for both stops.
text_html: The 55 is garbage (there, I said it) and I’m not sure 15-20 min frequency is all that frequent. I agree it’s not a clear win for 16th, but pier 70 is still easily a half mile walk from 22nd street. If we achieve metro-level Caltrain service, there’s an argument for both stops.

text:
No, you don't need transfer #1 unless you're coming from the Castro, Fillmore or beyond. The 55 comes to 16th St Mission BART.

But more importantly, Caltrain will be at Salesforce Transit Center, and you'll take BART to Embarcadero. It would be crazy not to prioritize DTX first.
text_html: No, you don't need transfer #1 unless you're coming from the Castro, Fillmore or beyond. The 55 comes to 16th St Mission BART. But more importantly, Caltrain will be at Salesforce Transit Center, and you'll take BART to Embarcadero. It would be crazy not to prioritize DTX first.

text:
There are also better alternatives to get there. 22 from BART or T from 4th/King are good, efficient options.

Losing Caltrain degrades access to Dogpatch developments more than it improves it for Mission Bay. No direct crosstown access. 16th/Miss to T transfer is a 7 min walk.
text_html: There are also better alternatives to get there. 22 from BART or T from 4th/King are good, efficient options. Losing Caltrain degrades access to Dogpatch developments more than it improves it for Mission Bay. No direct crosstown access. 16th/Miss to T transfer is a 7 min walk.

text:
Good planning is not yanking a rail station away from 2 massive just-approved developments built around the station.

Transferring from 22nd or 4th & King to the T works fine for accessing UCSF/Chase Center. Or BART to the 22.
text_html: Good planning is not yanking a rail station away from 2 massive just-approved developments built around the station. Transferring from 22nd or 4th & King to the T works fine for accessing UCSF/Chase Center. Or BART to the 22.

Looking at RHNA, we're even further from that goal.
